headline: Was Trumpâ€™s Endorsement of J.D. Vance for Senate a Mistake?
author: Stephen Green
sentences:
All you to do is go through the issues and see the gap between what his Populist supporters think he stands for and what his actual policy is, Here are a few examples:
The smallest gap is on immigration policy.
If you look at Trump's positions on the issues then you see he is not a Populist but a hybrid Eastern Establishment Republican/Tip O'Neill Democrat.
Trump is not hawk by any means but his instincts are McGovernite but in practice he foreign policy looks like a competent version of Jimmy Carter.
Trump may not support defund the police but he did support "criminal justice reform" better know as jailbreak legislation.
But Trump's policy is to increase US competitiveness through reduction in the tax and regulatory burden.

It doesn't matter who puts criminals back on the street the result is going
to be the same.
Populists confuse his support for border control for an opposition to all immigration.
Why do you think he supports Ukraine and killed a bunch Russian mercenaries in Syria.
Vance is your typical Bernie Sanders voter whose second choice was Donald Trump.
His Pacific policy looks like FDR's with China replacing Japan as the bad guy.
Like many Populists, he fell for Trump's superficial Populist rhetoric.
Populists thing Trump is a protectionists and anti-globalist.
Trump is against illegal immigration not legal immigration.
Populists think he is an isolationist and Putin's soulmate.
What would you expect from an international businessman?
I could go on but should get the idea.
Tariffs are just a negotiation tool.
He supports smart immigration.
Foreign policy.
Trade policy.
